item.title: As Turkey Coup Unfolded, ‘the Whole Night Felt Like Doomsday’
item.media:description: People took over a tank near the Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge during clashes with military forces in Istanbul early Saturday.
item.media:credit: Gurcan Ozturk/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Thousands of soldiers and officers were purged from the military as the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan sought to assert control.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: The Interpreter: Turkey Was an Unlikely Victim of an Equally Unlikely Coup
item.media:description: People stand on a damaged military tank in Ankara on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Emin Ozmen for The New York Times
item.description: The uprising appeared to diverge wildly from the usual patterns of such attempts. And for several reasons, Turkey should have been at little risk.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and AMANDA TAUB
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Turkey Rounds Up Thousands of Military Personnel
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government moved swiftly to re-establish control after the failure of the attempted coup.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Tumult in Turkey: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the coup plotters would “pay a heavy price.” The prime minister said 265 people had been killed and more than 2,800 military personnel had been detained.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: ISIS Claims Truck Attacker in France Was Its ‘Soldier’
item.media:description: Mourners at a makeshift memorial on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France, on Friday.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Officials said the attacker, Mohamed Lahouaiej Bouhlel, may have “radicalized himself very quickly.” Four of his acquaintances have been detained.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: France Agonizes Over Whether Truck Rampage Could Have Been Stopped
item.media:description: Flowers and candles on Saturday, left where victims died on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Many people in Nice and around the world are asking how a lone driver could so easily flout traffic rules and then race unimpeded through throngs of people.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: An Unfinished Bridge, and Partnership, Between Russia and China
item.media:description: Chinese and Russian workers at the Kimkano-Sutarsky mine in the Jewish Autonomous Oblast in June. The cost of transporting ore from Russia to China will be reduced if a rail bridge connecting the countries is completed.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The nations’ leaders are close, but the faltering project highlights a problem in their collaboration: elaborate plans, with little follow-through.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Top South Korean Prosecutor Arrested on Charges That He Accepted Bribes
item.description: Accused of taking payment from an online game maker, the official, Jin Kyung-joon, is the most senior Korean prosecutor ever arrested while in office.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development

item.title: In Wartime, Ghani Assumes Role of Comforting Afghans
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, center, with staff members and bodyguards at Dawood National Military Hospital in Kabul, last month.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani, whose security forces in 2015 sustained their highest death toll in years, has for months made condolence calls to relatives of those killed.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Terror Through the Eyes of Innocents: The Children in Nice
item.media:description: A relative paid tribute on Saturday to 4½-year-old Yanis Coviaux, who was killed in the truck attack along the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The attack during the Bastille Day fireworks show, an annual attraction for families, underscored the act’s brutality, with at least 10 children killed and leaving many with memories of trauma.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and LILIA BLAISE

item.title: An Exiled Cleric Denies Playing a Leading Role in Coup Attempt
item.media:description: Fethullah Gulen, a Turkish cleric living in exile in the United States, denied inspiring an attempted coup in his home country, saying “through military intervention, democracy cannot be achieved.”
item.media:credit: Charles Mostoller for The New York Times
item.description: Fethullah Gulen, accused by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of inspiring an effort to overthrow the Turkish government, compared Mr. Erdogan’s government to that of Nazi-era Germany.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE SAUL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Turkey Interrupts U.S. Air Missions Against ISIS at Major Base
item.media:description: Incirlik Air Base in Adana, Turkey, last year.
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Erikan/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: A Pentagon spokesman said United States officials were “working with the Turks to resume air operations there as soon as possible.”
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Abroad in America, Deciphering the 2016 Presidential Race
item.media:description: Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Ángel Franco/The New York Times
item.description: I hope to turn my focus as a foreign correspondent to illuminating the fears, hopes and motivations that are driving voters of every hue.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Spanish Archive Raises Franco-Era Ghosts and Shadows of a New Chasm
item.media:description: Family documents and photos long held by the Spanish government were finally returned to Pere Bartolomé, 93, at a ceremony in Catalonia this month. Mr. Bartolomé could recall the day Gen. Francisco Franco’s soldiers ransacked his village and confiscated the documents.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: Eighty years after the Spanish Civil War began, the return of family documents kept by the government shows that the consequences continue to ripple through Spain.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Attack in France Fuels Anti-Immigrant Parties on Europe’s Right
item.media:description: People brought flowers to a memorial for the victims of the attack in Nice, France, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The killing in Nice came at a time of political flux and gives populist movements and the far right new opportunities to press their case.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Pakistani Social Media Celebrity Dead in Apparent Honor Killing
item.media:description: Qandeel Baloch in June.
item.media:credit: M Jameel/Associated Press
item.description: Qandeel Baloch, a controversial figure on social media in Pakistan, was strangled on Friday night. The police have arrested her brother in connection with the case.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: How Killing of Prominent Separatist Set Off Turmoil in Kashmir
item.media:description: Indian paramilitary soldiers during curfew in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Friday.
item.media:credit: Dar Yasin/Associated Press
item.description: Kashmir is divided between India and Pakistan, and Indian-administered Kashmir has long been plagued by the aftershocks of an armed insurgency in the late 1980s.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: What in the World: Never Mind Grass-Fed, How About Elixir-Fed Meats?
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht
item.description: In China, meat from livestock fed on traditional herbal remedies fetches a premium price from health-conscious shoppers.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: What in the World: When the Planets Align, Delhi Drowns in a Chorus of ‘I Do’
item.media:description: Guests dancing at a wedding in New Delhi on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Vivek Singh for The New York Times
item.description: A certain astrological configuration is considered auspicious by many Indians, and in the capital it means something very specific: a wedding apocalypse.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: What in the World: In New Zealand, Lands and Rivers Can Be People (Legally Speaking)
item.description: In a deal with Maori groups, Parliament has agreed on a way to protect natural features without them being owned by anyone, including the state.
item.dc:creator: BRYANT ROUSSEAU

item.title: Bangladesh Police Deny Rescued Hostages Are in Their Custody
item.description: The police denied that they were still holding a British man and a University of Toronto student who have been missing since an attack on a restaurant.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China Cites Negligence as Cause of Landslide That Killed 73
item.media:description: Rescue workers searching for survivors after a landslide in Shenzhen, China, in December.
item.media:credit: Chinatopix, via Associated Press
item.description: A seven-month investigation concluded that a mountain of construction debris in Shenzhen collapsed in December after shoddy oversight and the improper storage of waste.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Turkey’s Coup That Wasn’t
item.media:credit: Gokhan Tan/Getty Images
item.description: A failed coup in Turkey does not mean democracy is the winner. In fact Erdogan may now undermine democracy further.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Women Who Are Cleaning Up
item.media:description: Theresa May.
item.media:credit: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
item.description: Britain gets a female prime minister, so now politics is like housework?
item.dc:creator: JULIA BAIRD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Cuba, a Country Frozen in Time
item.description: My land is an insular museum, stuck between the Iron Curtain and the industrial capitalism of the 1950s, and visitors view us an exotic species.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS MANUEL ÁLVAREZ

item.title: As Refugee Family Resettles in Sweden, 9-Year-Old Nephew Dies
item.media:description: While a nurse prepares a medicine, Nabih, 9, rests in a hospital bed next to an aunt, his brother Farid and his mother Shazia Nouri, right, at a hospital in Antalya, southern Turkey.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Ahmad Majid is one of millions of people swept up in a global refugee crisis; his resettlement in Sweden ended when his young nephew died this week.
item.dc:creator: ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Insider Podcasts: Gone: Global Warming Claims a Lake — and a Way of Life
item.media:description: The dry bed of Lake Poopó near Llapallapani.
item.media:credit: Josh Haner/The New York Times
item.description: The Andes bureau chief, Nicholas Casey, and the staff photographer Josh Haner give listeners a behind-the-scenes account of their article about a vanished lake.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN LEHMAN

item.title: Srebrenica: 21st Anniversary of Europe’s Worst Postwar Massacre
item.description: More than 8,000 men and boys were murdered in and around the city of Srebrenica in July 1995, the worst mass killing in Europe since World War II.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
